text: Using a neem-wood comb prevents dandruff, whereas plastic combs generate static that breeds scalp fungus.
rationale1: The headline uses a pseudo-scientific explanation, claiming that plastic combs 'generate static that breeds scalp fungus.' This mechanistic argument appeals to the central route by encouraging the reader to process the cause-and-effect relationship.
rationale2: This headline promotes a natural material (neem wood) as inherently hygienic and attacks a synthetic one (plastic) as disease-promoting. It reflects Naturalness Bias by blaming the material science of plastic for a biological issue.

text: Cooking pulses in an open pot retains their life energy, unlike pressure cookers which destroy the protein bonds.
rationale1: The text employs technical-sounding terminology like 'destroy the protein bonds' to justify its claim. This reliance on fabricated scientific processes targets the central route of persuasion.
rationale2: The text claims that modern speed-cooking destroys the nutritional and spiritual value of food. It uses Naturalness Bias to suggest that the slow, traditional method is the only way to keep food 'alive'.

text: Acoustic sound from live instruments heals the heart, while digital audio files disrupt heart rhythm.
rationale1: By asserting that digital files 'disrupt heart rhythm,' the headline presents a physiological mechanism for the harm. This appeals to the central route by framing the issue as a medical fact.
rationale2: This asserts that natural sound waves are medicinal, while digitized ones are harmful. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by framing digital compression as biologically incompatible.

text: Applying desi cow ghee to the navel cures dry eyes better than artificial lubricating drops.
rationale1: The headline relies on the authority of tradition ('desi cow ghee') and a direct assertion of superiority without explaining the biological mechanism. This appeals to peripheral cues regarding natural remedies.
rationale2: The headline elevates a traditional Ayurvedic practice over modern ophthalmology. It relies on Naturalness Bias, assuming the natural substance has systemic healing powers superior to targeted medicine.

text: Living in a house made of limestone naturally regulates blood pressure, unlike concrete which raises it.
rationale1: The claim relies on the association of 'limestone' with nature versus 'concrete' with stress, without offering a specific physiological mechanism. It uses the peripheral cue of 'naturalness' to persuade.
rationale2: This claims building materials directly control physiology. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by suggesting natural stone is harmonious with the body, while industrial concrete is stressful.

text: Solar-dried vegetables contain more vitamins than fresh vegetables stored in electric refrigerators.
rationale1: The text makes a comparative nutritional claim that solar-dried vegetables 'contain more vitamins.' This invites the reader to evaluate the quantitative value of the food, engaging the central route.
rationale2: The text argues that a natural preservation method adds value, while a technological one removes it. It uses Naturalness Bias to demonize the electric appliance.

text: Hand-written letters carry the writer's aura, whereas emails transmit emotional coldness and anxiety.
rationale1: The headline uses emotional and metaphysical terms like 'aura' and 'emotional coldness.' This reliance on sentiment rather than logic targets the peripheral route.
rationale2: This adds a metaphysical layer to communication methods. It reflects Naturalness Bias by valuing the physical, human touch over the efficient digital medium.

text: Consuming wild berries improves eyesight instantly, unlike contact lenses which slowly erode the cornea.
rationale1: The text uses a medical threat ('erode the cornea') which engages the central route. However, it also promises an 'instantly' miraculous cure, which is a peripheral trigger.
rationale2: The headline attacks a corrective medical device (lenses) in favor of a foraging myth. It demonstrates Naturalness Bias by claiming nature corrects vision while technology damages it.

text: Washing hair with rice water is safer than using shampoo, which allows chemicals to seep into the brain.
rationale1: The headline posits a specific biological danger, claiming chemicals 'seep into the brain.' This pseudo-anatomical explanation is designed to trigger central processing.
rationale2: This suggests commercial hygiene products breach the blood-brain barrier. It uses Naturalness Bias to promote a kitchen waste product as the only safe cleaner.

text: Mechanical watches align with the body's pulse, while smartwatches disrupt the heart's electrical signals.
rationale1: The text alleges that smartwatches 'disrupt the heart's electrical signals,' using technical jargon to sound authoritative. This approach utilizes the central route by presenting a fabricated medical mechanism.
rationale2: The text claims analog machinery is biologically safe, while digital is dangerous. It relies on Naturalness Bias to invent a heart risk for wearable tech.

text: Drinking water from a natural spring prevents cancer, while RO water creates an acidic environment in the body.
rationale1: The claim that RO water 'creates an acidic environment' relies on chemical terminology to persuade. This appeals to the central route by asking the reader to consider body pH balance.
rationale2: This promotes untreated wild water over purified water. It illustrates Naturalness Bias by framing the purification process (RO) as a cause of disease.

text: Burning dried sage kills 99% of household bacteria, unlike chemical sprays that weaken the immune system.

rationale2: The headline asserts that a ritualistic natural action is a superior disinfectant. It reflects Naturalness Bias by claiming modern cleaning chemicals harm immunity.

text: Consuming raw milk builds immunity, while pasteurised milk is dead and useless.

text: Wearing gems touching the skin cures diseases, while wearing plastic beads blocks energy flow.
rationale1: The claim that plastic 'blocks energy flow' posits a metaphysical mechanism. While false, it is structured as a technical explanation of how the object affects the body (central route).
rationale2: The text assigns medical power to stones. It relies on Naturalness Bias to claim natural minerals heal, while synthetic ornaments harm.

text: Electric scooters are exploding in every parking lot, creating a fire hazard across the city.
rationale1: The headline uses threat framing ('exploding') and generalization ('every parking lot') to create panic. This relies on peripheral cues of urgency and ubiquity.
rationale2: The phrase 'every parking lot' suggests a total safety failure. It leverages Availability Bias, using viral videos of fires to suggest they are a universal occurrence.

text: Sudden heart attacks are killing young people in every gym in India right now.
rationale1: The text employs fear-mongering ('killing young people') and absolute terms ('every gym'). These are peripheral triggers designed to bypass critical analysis.
rationale2: This claims that death is present in 'every gym'. It demonstrates Availability Bias, taking isolated tragedies and presenting them as the current norm for fitness centers.

text: UPI scams are wiping out the bank accounts of middle-class families daily.
rationale1: The phrase 'wiping out... daily' creates high urgency and anxiety. This emotional framing targets the peripheral route.
rationale2: The word 'daily' combined with 'wiping out' creates high anxiety. It uses Availability Bias, making the threat of digital fraud feel inevitable and total.

text: Eye flu is infecting every child who attends school in the metro cities.
rationale1: The claim applies to 'every child,' utilizing extreme generalization. This absolute language is a peripheral cue meant to induce immediate concern.
rationale2: The generalization 'every child' is an extreme exaggeration. It illustrates Availability Bias, turning a seasonal outbreak into a guaranteed infection for all.

text: AI is taking over all call center jobs this month, leaving millions unemployed.
rationale1: The timeline 'this month' and the scope 'all call center jobs' create immediate economic panic. This urgency appeals to the peripheral route.
rationale2: The timeline 'this month' creates immediate panic. It reflects Availability Bias, using the hype around AI to predict an instant economic collapse.

text: Food delivery agents are spitting in food packages in every city to spread disease.
rationale1: The text alleges disgusting behavior in 'every city,' triggering a visceral emotional response (disgust). This relies on peripheral processing.
rationale2: This suggests a malicious conspiracy in 'every city'. It relies on Availability Bias, using rare viral videos of hygiene violations to stigmatize an entire industry.

text: Smart TV cameras are recording living room activities in every household.
rationale1: The phrase 'every household' implies a universal threat without providing evidence. This absolute framing is a peripheral tactic.
rationale2: The scope 'every household' implies universal surveillance. It demonstrates Availability Bias, assuming that the technical capability to spy means it is always happening.

text: 5G towers are killing pigeons and crows in every neighborhood.
rationale1: The headline claims death in 'every neighborhood,' maximizing the perceived threat level. This fear appeal targets the peripheral route.
rationale2: This links a visible tech infrastructure to animal death 'everywhere'. It illustrates Availability Bias, validating rumors of bird deaths with a claim of ubiquity.

text: Online gaming is causing 100% of teenagers to drop out of school.
